I agree; but 1e-3 is what's used in Gazebo's math library, e.g.:

* [Vector3](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/3db618e7baa3c8a6a1db5e34cd220d24404a7960/gazebo/math/Vector3.cc?at=default#cl-318)
* [Quaternion](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/3db618e7baa3c8a6a1db5e34cd220d24404a7960/gazebo/math/Quaternion.cc?at=default#cl-484)
* [Angle](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/3db618e7baa3c8a6a1db5e34cd220d24404a7960/gazebo/math/Angle.cc?at=default#cl-140)

I'm not arguing that 1e-3 is a good value, but it is what we've apparently been using until now.  Note that, irrespective of how we defines the comparison operators here in `sdformat`, the 1e-3 tolerances listed above will remain in place in Gazebo's math library, which is probably the more important code.

I agree; but 1e-3 is what's used in Gazebo's math library, e.g.:

  • Vector3
  • Quaternion
  • Angle

I'm not arguing that 1e-3 is a good value, but it is what we've apparently been using until now. Note that, irrespective of how we defines the comparison operators here in sdformat, the 1e-3 tolerances listed above will remain in place in Gazebo's math library, which is probably the more important code.
